javadoc:
An implementation of a file chooser dialog. This class is designed to emulate the JFileChooser, but it removes the network locking issue. When a network drive is down, the JFileChooser can take several minutes to come up. Why use this file chooser over JFileChooser?? Let me enumerate the reasons...
  1. JFileChooser cannot show hidden/system files, but we can!
  2. JFileChooser does not properly consume key strokes (global actions in docking windows)
  3. This class is threaded, so loading delays do not lock the GUI
  4. This class provides shortcut buttons similar to those of the Windows native chooser

methods.name: setFileSelectionMode
methods.comment:
Sets the GhidraFileChooser to allow the user to just
 select files, just select
 directories, or select both files and directories.  The default is
 JFilesChooser.FILES_ONLY.

params.name: mode
params.comment:
the type of files to be displayed:
 
 GhidraFileChooser.FILES_ONLY
 GhidraFileChooser.DIRECTORIES_ONLY
 GhidraFileChooser.FILES_AND_DIRECTORIES

Returns the selected file. This can be set either by the  programmer via

 filename into the UI or selecting the file from a list in the UI.

Returns the selected files.  This will show the file chooser
@return the selected files; an empty array if cancelled or no file was selected

methods.comment: Returns the selected files.  This will show the file chooser

return.comment: the selected files; an empty array if cancelled or no file was selected

methods.javadoc:
Returns the selected file. This can be set either by the programmer via {@link #setSelectedFile(File)} or by a user action, such as either typing the filename into the UI or selecting the file from a list in the UI.

Note: this method can be called after the chooser has been shown, in which case the value returned has been validated by the chooser. Also, the method may be called while the chooser is showing (like from a test thread). In this case, the selected file will not have been validated by the chooser. @param show if true then the dialog is displayed @return the selected file; null if cancelled or no file was selected
methods.name: getSelectedFile
methods.comment:
Returns the selected file. This can be set either by the programmer
 via #setSelectedFile(File) or by a user action, such as either typing the filename
 into the UI or selecting the file from a list in the UI.
 
 Note: this method can be called after the chooser has been shown, in which case the
 value returned has been validated by the chooser.  Also, the method may be called
 while the chooser is showing (like from a test thread).  In this case, the selected file
 will not have been validated by the chooser.

params.name: show
params.comment: if true then the dialog is displayed

return.comment: the selected file; null if cancelled or no file was selected

methods.javadoc: Gets the file currently selected in the GUI
methods.name: getUserSelectedFileInDisplay
methods.comment: Gets the file currently selected in the GUI

methods.javadoc:
Sets the selected file. If the file's parent directory is not the current directory, changes the current directory to be the file's parent directory.

If the given file is a directory, then it's parent directory will be made the current directory and the directory represented by the file will be selected within the parent directory.

If the given file does not exist, then the following will happen:

  • If the parent directory of the file exists, then the parent directory will be made the current directory and the name of the file will be put into the filename textfield; otherwise,
  • If the parent file does not exist, then the selection is cleared.

If the given file is null, then the selected file state is cleared. @see #getSelectedFile @param file the selected file
methods.name: setSelectedFile
methods.comment:
Sets the selected file. If the file's parent directory is not the current directory,
 changes the current directory to be the file's parent directory.
 
 If the given file is a directory, then it's parent directory will be made the current
 directory and the directory represented by the file will be selected within the parent
 directory.
 
 If the given file does not exist, then the following will happen:
 
  If the parent directory of the file exists, then the parent directory will be made
      the current directory and the name of the file will be put into the filename
      textfield; otherwise,
  If the parent file does not exist, then the selection is cleared.
 
 
 If the given file is null, then the selected file state is cleared.

params.name: file
params.comment: the selected file

methods.name: getCurrentDirectory
methods.comment: Returns the current directory.

methods.javadoc:
Sets the current directory. Passing in null sets the file chooser to point to the user's default directory. This default depends on the operating system. It is typically the "My Documents" folder on Windows, and the user's home directory on Unix.
If the file passed in as currentDirectory is not a directory, the parent of the file will be used as the currentDirectory. If the parent is not traversable, then it will walk up the parent tree until it finds a traversable directory, or hits the root of the file system. @param directory the current directory to point to @see #getCurrentDirectory
methods.name: setCurrentDirectory
methods.comment:
Sets the current directory. Passing in null sets the
 file chooser to point to the user's default directory.
 This default depends on the operating system. It is
 typically the "My Documents" folder on Windows, and the user's
 home directory on Unix.
 
 If the file passed in as currentDirectory is not a
 directory, the parent of the file will be used as the currentDirectory.
 If the parent is not traversable, then it will walk up the parent tree
 until it finds a traversable directory, or hits the root of the
 file system.

params.name: directory
params.comment: the current directory to point to

methods.javadoc:
A callback method for clients that *know* the user has chosen a file(s), like a list with a mouse listener that validates a double-click.

If you don't know how to use this method, then don't call it! @param file the file chosen by the user
methods.name: userChoseFile
methods.comment:
A callback method for clients that *know* the user has chosen a file(s), like a
 list with a mouse listener that validates a double-click.
 
 
 If you don't know how to use this method, then don't call it!

params.name: file
params.comment: the file chosen by the user

name: GhidraFileChooser
comment:
An implementation of a file chooser dialog.
 This class is designed to emulate the JFileChooser,
 but it removes the network locking issue.
 When a network drive is down, the JFileChooser can
 take several minutes to come up.

 Why use this file chooser over JFileChooser??
 Let me enumerate the reasons...
 
  JFileChooser cannot show hidden/system files, but we can!
  JFileChooser does not properly consume key strokes (global actions in docking windows)
  This class is threaded, so loading delays do not lock the GUI
  This class provides shortcut buttons similar to those of the Windows native chooser

fields.javadoc: Instruction to display both files and directories.
fields.name: FILES_AND_DIRECTORIES
fields.comment: Instruction to display both files and directories.

fields.javadoc: Files selected by the user, but not yet validated.
fields.name: selectedFiles
fields.comment: Files selected by the user, but not yet validated.

fields.javadoc:
Selected files that have passed as acceptable.  These will be given back to the user.  When
 we say validation, we mean files that exist.  If the user chooses a file from the GUI by
 clicking it, then that file is valid, as it exists.  Alternatively, if the user types in
 a filename we need to perform validation on the entered value to make sure it is valid
 for the given context.  For example, if the chooser is in {@link #FILES_ONLY} mode,
 then we must not allow a directory to be chosen.
fields.name: validatedFiles
fields.comment:
Selected files that have passed as acceptable.  These will be given back to the user.  When
 we say validation, we mean files that exist.  If the user chooses a file from the GUI by
 clicking it, then that file is valid, as it exists.  Alternatively, if the user types in
 a filename we need to perform validation on the entered value to make sure it is valid
 for the given context.  For example, if the chooser is in #FILES_ONLY mode,
 then we must not allow a directory to be chosen.
